PermissibleValues.value: Digital Slide Image-Formalin FFPE Top Slide
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Digital Slide Image - FFPE Top Slide

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Digital Slide Image - FFPE Top Slide
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Photographic images captured electronically.: A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.: A colorless poisonous gas synthesized by the oxidation of methanol and used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, histologic fixative, and general-purpose chemical reagent for laboratory applications. Formaldehyde is readily soluble in water and is commonly distributed as a 37% solution in water; formalin, a 10% solution of formaldehyde in water, is used as a disinfectant and to preserve biological specimens. Environmentally, formaldehyde may be found in the atmosphere, smoke from fires, automobile exhaust and cigarette smoke. Small amounts are produced during normal metabolic processes in most organisms, including humans.: Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin.: Tissue that is preserved and embedded in paraffin.: The uppermost part, side, or surface of something.: A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

Concepts.definition: Photographic images captured electronically.
A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

A colorless poisonous gas synthesized by the oxidation of methanol and used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, histologic fixative, and general-purpose chemical reagent for laboratory applications. Formaldehyde is readily soluble in water and is commonly distributed as a 37% solution in water; formalin, a 10% solution of formaldehyde in water, is used as a disinfectant and to preserve biological specimens. Environmentally, formaldehyde may be found in the atmosphere, smoke from fires, automobile exhaust and cigarette smoke. Small amounts are produced during normal metabolic processes in most organisms, including humans.
Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin.
Tissue that is preserved and embedded in paraffin.
The uppermost part, side, or surface of something.
A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Physical Formalin Fixed Paraffin Embedded Slide Image

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Physical Formalin Fixed Paraffin Embedded Slide Image
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having substance or material existence; concerned with material things; of or pertaining to the body as distinguished from the mind or spirit. : A colorless poisonous gas synthesized by the oxidation of methanol and used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, histologic fixative, and general-purpose chemical reagent for laboratory applications.  Formaldehyde is readily soluble in water and is commonly distributed as a 37% solution in water; formalin, a 10% solution of formaldehyde in water, is used as a disinfectant and to preserve biological specimens. Environmentally, formaldehyde may be found in the atmosphere, smoke from fires, automobile exhaust and cigarette smoke.  Small amounts are produced during normal metabolic processes in most organisms, including humans. (NCI04): Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin.: Paraffin is a common name for a group of high molecular weight alkane hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is between 22 and 27. Paraffin is also a technical name for an alkane in general, but in most cases it refers specifically to a linear, or normal alkane. It is mostly found as a white, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid, with a melting point between 47C and 65C. It is insoluble in water, but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but oxidizes readily. (from Wikipedia): To surround a pathological or histological specimen with a firm and sometimes hard medium such as paraffin, wax, celloidin, or a resin, in order to make possible the cutting of thin sections for microscopic examination. (On-line Medical Dictionary): A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.: Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic.

Concepts.definition: Having substance or material existence; concerned with material things; of or pertaining to the body as distinguished from the mind or spirit.

A colorless poisonous gas synthesized by the oxidation of methanol and used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, histologic fixative, and general-purpose chemical reagent for laboratory applications. Formaldehyde is readily soluble in water and is commonly distributed as a 37% solution in water; formalin, a 10% solution of formaldehyde in water, is used as a disinfectant and to preserve biological specimens. Environmentally, formaldehyde may be found in the atmosphere, smoke from fires, automobile exhaust and cigarette smoke. Small amounts are produced during normal metabolic processes in most organisms, including humans.
Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin.

A common name for a group of high molecular weight alkane hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is between 22 and 27. Paraffin is also a technical name for an alkane in general, but in most cases it refers specifically to a linear, or normal alkane. It is mostly found as a white, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid, with a melting point between 47C and 65C. It is insoluble in water, but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but oxidizes readily.
To surround an object with a firm chemical substance such as wax or resin, in order to perform cutting of thin sections for microscopic examination.
A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.
Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The action of spreading a thin layer of material across a surface.

Concepts.definition: The action of spreading a thin layer of material across a surface.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A thin slice of tissue cut from a frozen specimen, often used for rapid microscopic diagnosis.

Concepts.definition: A thin slice of tissue cut from a frozen specimen, often used for rapid microscopic diagnosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A microscope slide prepared by depositing cells directly onto a slide by centrifugation. The cytocentrifuge spins at an angle, at low speeds, allowing the cells to adhere to the slide in a monolayer format.

Concepts.definition: A microscope slide prepared by depositing cells directly onto a slide by centrifugation. The cytocentrifuge spins at an angle, at low speeds, allowing the cells to adhere to the slide in a monolayer format.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A colorless poisonous gas synthesized by the oxidation of methanol and used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, histologic fixative, and general-purpose chemical reagent for laboratory applications. Formaldehyde is readily soluble in water and is commonly distributed as a 37% solution in water; formalin, a 10% solution of formaldehyde in water, is used as a disinfectant and to preserve biological specimens. Environmentally, formaldehyde may be found in the atmosphere, smoke from fires, automobile exhaust and cigarette smoke. Small amounts are produced during normal metabolic processes in most organisms, including humans.: Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin.: Tissue that is preserved and embedded in paraffin.: A very thin slice (of tissue or mineral or other substance) for examination under a microscope.

Formaldehyde is readily soluble in water and is commonly distributed as a 37% solution in water; formalin, a 10% solution of formaldehyde in water, is used as a disinfectant and to preserve biological specimens. Environmentally, formaldehyde may be found in the atmosphere, smoke from fires, automobile exhaust and cigarette smoke. Small amounts are produced during normal metabolic processes in most organisms, including humans.
Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin.

A very thin slice (of tissue or mineral or other substance) for examination under a microscope.
